he took this book by Pushkin and he did some statistics on it so he was working
out like What proportion of the vowels are followed by more vowels What proportion of the vowels are followed by consonants and things like that and he
was working out the statistics of it and then using that he was able to create a statistical model of how the language
anguage was structured and how going from whichever letter you are at the moment you might get to a different letter based on probabilities but he
didn't actually use that to generate any novel text he was just using it to investigate the stats around the Russian
text that he could find at the time um now the first person who did use this approach to generate test at least as
far as I can tell was this guy Claude Shannon and he is a bit of a legend in
information theory he defined a lot of the mathematics of how we know how much signal we can get through a channel and
things like that still very relevant today and he took markov's work and he
um showed that we can flip the probabilities around and use it as a way of generating text which is kind of an
obvious idea in retrospect uh I'm not sure if anyone did it before Shannon but he he got it into one of his um most
famous papers and uh he gave an example like this so let's say that we want to
generate text one character at a time so what we might do is take some Source text and work out the statistics of it
so say for all the A's in this text What proportion of them are followed by another a What proportion of them are
followed by another by a b and so on and we work out this big Matrix of all the combinations and then we can generate
some text so let's say arbitrarily we decide to start at C just randomly okay
and then we output a c then we can pick the next letter according to the statistics so there's a higher
proportion chance it's going to be a an a then a b following a c so maybe that's the one we happen to pick so now we
output an A and then we move our state machine over to a then we can pick the next letter according to the
probabilities there maybe we happen to pick a b at that point so we output that and then we move to B and we use the
probabilities there to pick the next letter and so on and we can keep going uh for as long as we like and whatever
text we output will follow the same statistical properties as whatever Source language we used to define these
